platform I I read about that and you
used the disruptor framework yes can you
explain a little bit about this
framework so we created the disruptor
because we um we did the good scientific
thing and measured our system trying to
get the latency down as low as possible
and um we created the disruptor when we
found that the cues in between the
different stages in our pipeline was the
highest latency part of the system not
the bit not the interesting bit that's
doing the business logic but just
queuing things from system to system and
so the disruptor is is just a very very
quick way of doing that um but rather
than just being a much faster queue
which is where we originally started we
realized that what we could do is have a
single data structure which would be a
central place for all the different bits
of the to get what they wanted from it
so rather than having to send it here
and then here and then here we have it
in this Central ring buffer ring buffer
and then we wire out the dependencies of
the different parts of the pipeline to
fetch it when we need it so you get much
faster execution you get really nice um
batching behavior from the fact that
it's a ring buffer um and you get this
really nice way to manage your
dependencies and and and see the way
that the work flows through the system
and what about there's no need for
and it's kind of it's completely lock
free and that's what gives it that's
what gives it the speed um everything's
managed by sequence numbers so this ring
buffer has a sequence number to say
where it's written to the most recent
it's written to each of the things which
reads from it has a sequence number to
say where it's got up to as well and
it's these sort of magic sequence
numbers which coordinate everything so
if I've got something down here at the
end of the pipeline which needs to make
sure that all of these have finished
doing what they're doing all it has to
do is read the sequence numbers of those
things rather get notified or rather
than wait on any locks and and the
sequence numbers can be volatile so then
that way anything that happens before
you update your sequence number has
definitely happened so when you're when
sequence number updates then you've got
you've got all the rights that happened
in the ring buffer we don't have to lock
anything at all it's all just done with
s of volatiles memory barriers and and
